Macron, a vulnerable president after one dissolution and two failed governments
subhead: The fall of Prime Minister François Bayrou ushers in a new period of political instability. The French president, widely seen as responsible for the crisis within his own ranks, now faces pressure from the opposition to propose a new candidate for the post of prime minister.
byline: By Mariama Darame and Nathalie Segaunes

title: 'The proposed tax on France's highest net worths could reduce the deficit by €5 billion, not €20 billion'
subhead: Seven economists, including Philippe Aghion, Christian Gollier and Emmanuelle Taugourdeau, say in an op-ed for Le Monde that the 'Zucman tax' would not yield the expected revenue and would face legal, economic and behavioral obstacles.

title: French borrowing costs soar after PM falls
subhead: The yield on 10-year French bonds rose to 3.48% on Tuesday, compared to 3.47% for Italian bonds, traditionally the worst in Europe.

title: French startup Mistral raises €1.7 billion, cementing AI lead in Europe
subhead: Mistral raised €1.7 billion on Tuesday and sealed a partnership with Dutch chipmaking giant ASML, doubling the AI startup's valuation to €11.7 billion.

title: 'If Bayrou fell, it is because he refused the golden rule: first build a majority'
subhead: Constitutional scholar Denis Baranger views the Bayrou government's fall as the logical outcome of 'one man's pretension' to govern 'without a majority or a program.' Resolving the crisis will require going back to the parliamentary system's mechanisms.

Did Macron really add €1 trillion to France's national debt?
subhead: While this figure often cited by opposition parties is misleading, France's debt has risen significantly under Emmanuel Macron's presidency, partly due to his tax policy decisions.

title: Alison Bechdel, cartoonist: 'How can you argue with people who don't use logic?'
subhead: In 'Spent: A Comic Novel,' Bechdel depicts a queer community under siege by Trumpism, with self-deprecating humor. The Cartoonmuseum Basel in Switzerland is dedicating a retrospective to her work through October 26.

title: 'Block Everything': While September 10 movement echoes the Yellow Vests, it also has key differences
subhead: While the call to 'block everything' on Wednesday, September 10, brings to mind the Yellow Vest protests of 2018, the choice of a weekday, the involvement of unions, and the support of left-wing parties give this social movement its own distinct character.
